Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of Nov. 13th, I beg to say that the teacher on the Spanish is too much interested to be a reliable person in the case.

The children are not Protestant except only a very small number of them, and this might be proved by the register of baptisms. It is proved also by the fact that the parents gave themselves as Catholics when Dr. Fulton started took the Census. But on account of the school being a Protestant one, and the use of the school building being granted only to the minister, the whole appearance of the place is more Protestant like.

You understand easily, dear Sir, how I am obliged in duty to look after that matter—and try to obtain that Catholics may have as well as others the benefit of the law.

As for the school at Thessalon, you may remember that it is after taking your advice that I did not change the teacher as I already wanted.
to Mr. You will kindly let me know when it will be advisable to find a suitable person for the vacant office.

Mr. Sweery who was teaching at Sagamook, and whom I did not change in the summer in consideration of your opinion that it was better to give him another chance, wrote to me lately saying that he was leaving the school to his wife until I find a more competent teacher. I informed the Department.

S. Remai, dear Sir,

You servant in the Lord.

J. A. Artes

Sheraton Nov 23rd 1859

Sir,

Enclosed please find some letters which I have received from Mr. Acton Reed at Wikwemikong, Manitoulin Island, one from the Rev. Mr. Frost, Indian Missionary, and one from the Bishop of Algoma. It appears by what I can learn that the Church of England Indians themselves in that part of the Spanish River reserve called Division No. 2 baptised some of them and brought them from Heathcote, now the Indians are after them and want to take the school from them.

I would have written to the bishop before but I was waiting for a reply from Rev. Mr. Frost so I got his letter last night and hasten to send it to you with its other correspondence.

Those families who the Bishop says live down the river near our school I tried to make peace among them by telling the teacher not to teach religion during school hours, but it seems nothing will do but have the school closed.

I am in your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir,

Enclosed please find a report of Spanish River Indian School. This school is not getting along as well as I could wish. Their seems to be a division among the people in religious matters. The present teacher Miss Morley spends all her small earnings on the children to keep them at school. She is an old lady who thinks this is her mission—a sort of an enthusiasm in her calling.

I hope we will do better in the near future.

Your obedient servant,
Samuel Heywood
Indian agent

of Indian Affairs

My dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of Oct. 25 regarding the Indian School at the Spanish River Reserve, Mr. Stewart wrote me on the 6th inst., in terms that somewhat exaggerated my meaning.

My purpose in writing was not to secure the closing of the school but to ask what in case the question of closing it should come up and be decided affirmatively our request to buy the building for missionary purposes should be at once considered as far as possible granted.

May I have the pleasure of your reply?

I am

Very faithfully yours,

George Algoma

19th September 1904

Sir,

I regret very much to say that through ill health our teacher for Spanish River Indian school had to give up teaching and the school has not been opened at any time during this quarter. I say to say that Miss Carrie Dunley was one of our best teachers. She taught the school for twelve years and spent all she had among the Indians. She left this place very poor.

I would recommend that she receive an annuity as she is a very old woman and gave the best of her life to doing a good work among the poor Indians. I do not think it would be wise to open the above school as the attendance has been very poor lately. On that part of the reserve the Indians are scattered and live too far from the school house.

Your obedient servant,
Samuel Hogan
Indian Agent

OTTAWA, September 26th—1904.,
Department of Indian Affairs.

Memorandum:

For the Deputy Sup't. General,

Mr. Agent Hagan reports that Miss Carrie Morley who has been teaching the Spanish River School for over 12 years has been obliged to resign on account of ill health. It has been frequently reported to the Department that Miss Morley was most energetic and self-sacrificing in the discharge of her duties, and owing to her generosity and small stipend she received she is living in poor health and poor circumstances. Mr. Hagan recommends that she receive an annuity. She is an old woman and will not be able to resume her profession. We have no provision for the superannuation of our teachers, but as this school will not be re-opened, I think the Department will be justified, in view of her past services, in continuing her salary to the end of the year.

His Lordship the Bishop of Algoma, in whose diocese this school is situated, wrote some two years ago asking the Department in the event of the school being closed that he should be permitted to buy the school building for missionary purposes. I would suggest that Mr. Hagan be asked to place a valuation on the building (and that His Lordship be advised of the Department's intention to close the school.)

[Signature]

OTTAWA, 30th November, 1904

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 19th September last, regarding the case of Miss Carrie Morley, late teacher of the Spanish River Indian school, I beg to say that the Department regrets its inability to meet your wishes in regard to an annuity, but in view of the circumstances, it will pay her six months salary as a retiring allowance, and a cheque for $75.00 has been sent you on this account, which you will be good enough to forward to Miss Morley's address. This will be followed by a second cheque for the same amount at the end of the year.

Please advise the Department as to the probable value of this building, as it has a prospect of disposing of it.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sainte-Marie Oct. 4th 1904

Dear Mr. Nagan,

The St. Patrick's Reserve School is now closed. This Monday has gone; and the question arises, what is to be done in the future?

Will the Indian Department entertain the idea of appointing another teacher? If so, I might suggest a name from the Indians when they have last desired me to do so. What had I better do?

Of course you know a deal
as I do, or better perhaps,
the circumstances of the case; and can form an idea whether the children are likely to come to school to another teacher. If Dr. Scott says he would like to send a male, I would be very glad to send some one who could take a little charge for the Church on Sundays.

Kindly let me know as soon as convenient, as there is no time to be lost.

Believe me

faithfully yours,

George Agoon
Indian Office
Sherbrooke
9th December 1904

Sir,

In answer to your letter of the 30th ultimo and numbered as above, I beg to tender my sincerest thanks for your kindness in providing for his immediate wants, and I beg to assure you that your kindness has not been misplaced.

As to the school building on Spanish River reserve I beg to say that it is well worth one hundred and fifty dollars.

I have received a letter from the Bishop of Algoma which I now enclose which bears somewhat on that business. You will see by his Lordship's letter what his ideas are on the matter.

Your obedient servant,
Samuel Hagan
Indian Agent

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, and in reply I beg to say that a further cheque will be sent to you for Miss Carrie Morley, late Spanish teacher of the Spanish River Indian school.

With regard to the enquiry contained in the letter addressed to you by His Lordship, the Bishop of Algoma, on the 4th Oct., last relative to the appointment of another teacher for this school, I beg to say that in view of your statement that you do not consider that it would be wise to re-open the school, the Department cannot see its way to meeting His Lordship's wishes.

Two years ago His Lordship, the Bishop of Algoma proposed to buy the school building for mission purposes in the event of the Department finding it necessary to close the school. In view of the circumstances it will be willing to sell the building at your valuation of $150.00 and you may advise the Bishop accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

Samuel Hagan, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.

J. D. McLean
Secretary

Sir,

I beg to say that Spanish Band 2nd Division, are desirous of having their school opened, and I understand his Lordship the Bishop of Algoma has a young man in view, who will teach the school and hold services on Sunday there are 12 or 14 children who would profit by the school being opened. Ottawa, December 11, 1905.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr. Agent Hagan writes stating that the Spanish River band are anxious to have their school re-opened. A teacher is available and he says that there are 12 or 14 children who would attend.

This school was closed a year ago last June owing to the retirement of Miss Morley, who had been in charge for a number of years, and the falling off in attendance. Money for the teacher's salary is voted, and apparently the Indians have profited by being deprived of the school for over a year.

I think the Department would be justified in giving it another trial. If approved of I would suggest that Mr. Hagan be asked to submit the name of the teacher the Bishop of Algoma has in view.

[Signature]

Ottawa, December 12, 1905.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th inst., reporting that the Spanish River band are anxious to have their school re-opened, as there are twelve or fourteen children who could attend, and that a teacher is available.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will consent to this school being given another trial, and you may ask His Lordship the Bishop of Algoma to submit to the Department for its approval the name of the teacher he proposes to engage, with his qualifications.

You will attend to this matter at once, so that the school may be re-opened as early in January as possible.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.
Dear Mr. Hagan,

The young man I have in mind for the School at Spanish River is Mr. Richard Dollon, an Irishman educated at the Masonic College in Dublin.

Of his ample qualifications I have not the slightest doubt.

He is ready to come at any time. If he is to live in the School House I hope it will be put in order so work should be got to heat it. He is married or may prefer to live in slavery to go up daily to his work.

Let me know at once when he is appointed.

Faithfully yours,

George Hagan

Dear Mr. Hagan,

I have no personal acquaintance with Miss Cadotte. I am credibly informed that she is not on the strength. What I have heard I believe her to be quite qualified in knowledge and willing to teach the School on the Spanish River Reserve.

But I learn her age is not yet quite 18 years of age, and I do not think she can possess the usual Teacher's certificate. If you are willing under the circumstances to accept her I shall be glad.

Faithfully yours,

Right Reverend Sir,

In accordance with the expressed wish of Your Lordship Miss Margaret Cadotte was appointed last fall to take charge of the Spanish River school.

Her services as teacher have proved satisfactory, and she has been advised that, should she desire to remain in charge of the school, the Department will be pleased to continue her engagement next year.

I trust that this action will meet with the approval of Your Lordship.

MEMORANDUM:—

Assistant Secretary.

The Spanish River school has for the past two years been taught by Miss Margaret Cadotte. Miss Cadotte is the holder of a District Non-professional certificate. The reports from the Public School Inspector on the work being performed at this school are exceedingly satisfactory and Mr. MacKay, who recently visited the reserve, states that the teacher is doing good work and is very popular with the Indians. It is an expensive place to live as she has to board in the village. Her salary is only $300.00 per annum and the inspector recommends a substantial increase.

The policy of the Department of late has been to increase the salary of deserving teachers and provision has been made for the necessary funds. I would, therefore, recommend that Miss Cadotte's salary be increased to $400.00 per annum from the 1st of July, last.

Martin Beavon
Ottawa, August 4, 1910.

Madam,

In view of the satisfactory work being performed by you as teacher of the Spanish River school it has been decided to increase your salary to $400.00 per annum from the 1st of July last.

The Department would be very glad to have a personal report from you dealing with your work at this school and also to know whether you would be willing to take up the teaching of some branch of domestic science, say sewing, to the children and whether a garden might not be cultivated in connection with the school. Many of our teachers now are taking up these two branches and are meeting with a great deal of success, as they prove of interest to the children and result in an increased and more regular attendance.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Secretary.

Miss Margaret Cadotte,
Massey, Ont.
Ottawa, August 4, 1910.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that in view of the satisfactory services of Miss Cadotte, teacher of the Spanish River school, her salary has been increased to $400.00, to date from the first of July, last.

Ottawa July 6, 1911.

Sir,

With reference to the quarterly return of the Spanish River school for the quarter ended June 30, last, forwarded by you, I beg to draw attention to the holidays taken by Miss Cadotte, the teacher during that quarter.

The return shows that the school was closed twenty-four days and no reasons are given by either the teacher or yourself as to why the school was closed during that time. In all cases full particulars together with the dates of all holidays should be given on the return and in future would like you to be good enough to see that this is done.

Some explanation should be furnished by the teacher as to her reasons for closing the school twenty-four days during the June quarter.

Your obedient servant

Asst. Deputy and Secretary

Samuel Hagan, Esq.,
Indian Agent
Thessalon, Ont.

Referring to that portion of your report on the Spanish River School for the month of November in which you state that Miss Cadotte has resigned her position I beg to say that you should forward this resignation to the Department. Ottawa, December 7, 1911.

Right Reverend Sir,

The Department is informed by Mr. Agent Hagan that Miss Cadotte, teacher of the Spanish River School, has resigned. No reason for this resignation is given and the Department regrets very much that Miss Cadotte has found it necessary to discontinue the work.

I have to ask Your Lordship to be good enough to take such steps as you consider necessary at an early date with a view of obtaining a successor who will take charge after the Christmas holidays. Miss Cadotte was paid a salary of $400.00 and a successor with qualifications will receive the same amount. I shall be glad to hear from Your Lordship in reference to this matter.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Right Rev. George Thorneles, D.D., D.C.L.,
Bishop of Algoma,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Ottawa, April 19, 1912.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant reporting the destruction by fire of the woodshed at the Spanish River School.

In reply I have to ask you to be good enough to obtain an estimate of the cost of rebuilding, with recommendations as to how the work should be done.

The Department wishes to have a survey conducted in connection with this school this year and in order to do so it will be necessary to have some fencing done. Kindly submit an estimate of the cost of this work, the labour to be performed by the Indians and the material supplied by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Samuel Hagan, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.
Sir,

Enclosed please find Agent's report for Spanish River Indian day school situated on the North side of the reserve on the Bank of the Spanish River. I beg leave to draw your attention to the fact that some of the children live over three miles from the school house and have very poor roads. The Teacher suggest the idea to have these children stop at the school but it is too much to ask her to provide food for these children. If the Department would allow us to purchase a few necessaries to provide food for the children, say during the winter it would be an excellent thing.

I beg leave to say that the Teacher and her mother is now living at the school house and will keep it clean as the same figure the others do viz. $1.00 per month so we will not require the Chief's attendance any more, hoping these suggestions will find favor in your sight.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Samuel Hogan
Indian Agent
Sheraton P.O.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Ottawa, November 14, 1912.

Sir,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, and in reply I beg to say that if arrangements can be made to have the children who live at a distance from the Spanish River School live with the teacher during the winter the Department will be prepared to assist in furnishing the food supplies. The Indians themselves, however, should be required to provide at least a portion of them and to clothe the children. At some of the other schools in Ontario this practice is followed, but in no case is the Department asked to furnish all the food supplies. I have to ask you to be good enough to submit a list of these necessary articles with an estimate of the cost.

During my recent visit to the Spanish River Reserve, a delegation of Indians living along the Spanish River, headed by Mr. Yaomana, Anglican clergyman of Massey and Indian missionary asked me to draw the attention of the Department to the urgent necessity of providing a small protestant day school for the Spanish River Reserve.

There is already one school (Roman Catholic) at Sagamok on the Lake Huron shore which is sufficient for the requirements of Band No.1 who live in that part of the Reserve, and until two years ago a small school (log hall) was open as a day school for the needs of the Protestant Indians living along the Spanish River. This school has however been closed for two years as the building is very dilapidated, quite unfit for occupation, and as I am given to understand has been condemned.

As will be seen by the attached sketch plan of the Reserve the Indian population has, due to topographical conditions of the Reserve, separated into two distinct settlements; a river settlement along the shore of the Spanish River, being composed mostly of Protestant Indians and a lake settlement on the shore of Lake Huron, composed mainly of Indians professing the Roman Catholic faith.

These two settlements are approx. 6 miles apart and the necessity of having two schools is therefore apparent. As the river settlement consists of 15 houses having a population of 78 Indians I submit a list of the Indian families comprising this settlement, showing the number of children in each family. Although there are 42 children in all, only 31 of these are of school age.

I would therefore suggest that if at all possible, arrangements be made for the construction of a small frame day school having a capacity for at least 25 children, and that a new site be selected at the point indicated on the attached sketch, which in my opinion is more central, and which the Indians themselves approve of.

H. Bury
Supervisor Indian Timber Lands.

Memorandum:

THE DEPUTY MINISTER,

I am in receipt of Mr. Pratt's memorandum of May 17th, regarding a letter which he has received from Mr. Thomas Farquhar, M.P., in connection with the teacher at the Spanish River Anglican Indian Day School.

The position of teacher at this school became vacant at the end of June, 1936, owing to the resignation of the teacher in charge at that time. The Right Reverend Rockesborough R. Smith, M.A., D.D., Bishop of Algoma, nominated a married woman to take charge of the school, but the Department refused to consider her nomination in view of the requirements of Section 36 (1) of the Civil Service Regulations. The Bishop was unable to secure another teacher, and, as the Department had an application from a qualified teacher, Miss Hazel Crooks, who is an Anglican, her appointment was approved and she began duties on September 1st, 1936.

In April, 1936, the Bishop wrote the Department, stating that Miss Crooks was not giving enough attention to religious teaching at the school. At that time Miss Crooks was written and requested to cooperate with the local missionary. She replied stating that she was doing so.

I have carefully reviewed the Inspector's reports covering her work, and all of these seem eminently satisfactory. I have taken the following excerpt from the Public School Inspector's last report, dated November 10, 1936: "The teacher is capable and is giving her best to her work. She has the confidence of the pupils and they are working in harmony with her".

The Department is primarily interested in the work accomplished in the school by the teacher and only in a secondary sense in her missionary efforts in the community. In view of the reports regarding her work, which have been received, I cannot recommend the dismissal of Miss Crooks at this time.

Director.

I have your letter of November 5 in connection with the selection of a teacher for the Spanish River Indian Day School.

Present regulations do not permit our engaging married women as teachers. I may add that there are very many highly qualified teachers without employment in the Province of Ontario at the present time and I feel confident that you will have no difficulty in securing one of these.

As mentioned in my letter of November 2, you should give full particulars regarding the teacher nominated by you.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

The Rt. Rev. R.R. Smith, M.A., D.D.,
Bishop of Algoma,
Bishopurat
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Ottawa, January 26, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, enclosing a communication from Rev. F. W. Colloton, Sault Ste. Marie, nominating the services of Mrs. Buell, Massey, Ont., for the position of teacher of the new Spanish River Indian Day School, and stating the qualifications which she possesses.

In reply I beg to say that in view of the difficulty in obtaining a qualified teacher at this time the Department will approve of the temporary appointment of Mrs. Buell until the end of June, next. We note that Mrs. Buell has two small children, and in this connection it is expected that she will free herself from domestic duties and devote all necessary time and energy to the classroom work at this school. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $50 per teaching month. I shall be pleased if you will inform the Church authorities accordingly, and arrange with Mrs. Buell to begin duties as soon as the school is ready. Please give Mrs. Buell every assistance you can upon her taking up duties at this school. You should impress upon the Indian parents the necessity of seeing that their children of school age who are in good health attend regularly.

Please report later the date upon which Mrs. Buell begins duties and also state her Christian name in full, as well as the arrangements she has made for the caring of her children in order that she will be able to devote the necessary time to the classroom duties.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, April 24, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, enclosing a communication from Mrs. Jean Buell, teacher of the Spanish River Indian Day School, in which she requests that authority be granted for her to continue teaching during the month of July, next, in order that she can carry on gardening operations with the pupils.

In reply I beg to say that, after fully considering this matter, it is thought that it would be advisable to allow the teacher to continue teaching during the month of July and to take holidays during the month of August. The school should be reopened on September 1st, next, the same time as the other Indian day schools open, and the second months' holidays could be taken in January, 1929, at which time, owing to weather conditions, it might be advisable to have the school closed. I shall be pleased if you will discuss this arrangement with the teacher, and inform the Department as to whether you would recommend that the holiday period be taken during August and January instead of during July and August, as is done in the case of nearly all the other Indian day schools.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

C. Rothera, Esq.,

Ottawa, May 15, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, relative to the holiday period at the Spanish River Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the present teacher, Mrs. Buell, should continue teaching during the month of July, next, and take holidays during the month of August. The school should be re-opened on or about September 1st, next, and the second months' holidays taken in January, 1929. You will be good enough to inform Mrs. Buell accordingly, and instruct her to comply with the Department's requirements as to the annual holidays at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

MEMORANDUM:

Representative of the Treasury.

Re: No. 435.

As no definite arrangements have yet been made regarding the teaching services at the Spanish River Indian Day School for the academic year 1935-36, this school should be omitted from the pay list for the month of September, 1935.
Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department is approving of the appointment of Miss Hazel Crooks as teacher of the Spanish River Indian Day School. Miss Crooks is a member of the Anglican Church. She possesses a First Class Interim Certificate. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $80 per teaching month. Besides teaching services, she will also carry out the janitor's work, for which she will be paid at the same rate as Miss Thornton, the former teacher, received, viz.: $4.00 per month.

Miss Crooks will arrive at Manseay Saturday morning, the 21st instant, and I have to request that you will either yourself arrange to meet her there or have the Anglican Missionary do so and accompany her to the school.

Should it be necessary to supply any equipment for the living quarters, you may arrange for the purchase of the supplies absolutely required at the present time. Some bedding, such as blankets and sheets, may be necessary, if the former teacher did not leave a supply at the school. Besides, some dishes, etc., may be required. Should any furniture be required, you may inform the Department immediately what is necessary and give an estimate of the cost.

The Department will rely on you to see that Miss Crooks is given every assistance upon her taking up duties. It is expected that she will re-open the school on Monday, the 23rd instant; when it is hoped she will meet with every success.

I may add His Lordship the Bishop of Algoma has been informed of the appointment of Miss Crooks.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

C. Rothera, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.

Sir:

I have the honor to inform you of the following communication from Mr. Smith, teacher of the Spanish River Indian School, and I would respectfully ask for instructions as to what steps to take in regard thereto.

I am very sorry to hear that you have been subjected to such a great misfortune that happened to us today (18th Inst.). The school house is burnt. It took fire on the roof, we think from a spark. There was not a man at hand. There was a pretty high wind at the time and everything was very dry. Before we got help it was beyond control. We saved all we could but we have lost a great deal. It put the things that were saved in a vacant house near by. The Indians said we could have it. If it was refused it would answer very well for a school house in the mean time. Please telegraph what I had better do.

This Letter

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
"get it ready to open school?"

"The Indians are returning from the sugar bush this week. I anticipated opening school tomorrow. Everything that was in our living room was burnt except most of our clothes and bedding; but our new warming stove that I had just managed to pay for, our cooking stove, dishes and utensils of our house, all effects were burnt."

"I have saved most of the school room furniture, except the stove and one map. I am anxiously awaiting your reply," etc.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

your obedient servant,

[Signature]

My dear Sir,

I informed you, shortly after the event,
of the burning of the School House at the Spanish
River Reserve. Since the fire Miss Morley,
the Teacher, acting & taking upon your instructions,
has been carrying on her School under great
difficulty in a little Cottage which was
fortuitously vacant at the time of the fire. She
has the use of this Cottage, incidentally only
with the Indians. It becomes necessary therefore
to consider what is to be done for the future.
In any case, were it at her disposal for a longer
period, the Cottage is not suited to the purpose
for a school; and something should be towards
rebuilding.

I called the Indians again on the 6th

July 19th 1848
and talked the matter over with them. They are anxious to have a new School Room. The last, as the last was, as a Mission School under the management of the Church of England, to which they belong, with few exceptions.

There are 8 heads of families belonging to the Church, and about others. There are 26 children attending more or less regularly at the School. A boy recently received into the missionary Home from this School was present by my appearance as a very well trained lad.

The Indians are willing to give labour in the rebuilding of the School; but they ask that materials be furnished to build with. It would probably also be necessary to have a little skilled labour. If so, it would be through the Church, not suitable building. I shall be glad to hear what the Department's views upon the subject are, and to what extent we may look to it, in the present emergency, for succour. I believe materials were promised for the old School by the Department.

Believe me Very faithfully Yours

George Algoma

Ottawa, 9th September, 1898.

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned has the honour to report that the Spanish River Band in Council has passed a Resolution requesting that the school-house which was recently destroyed by fire on their Reserve be rebuilt, and that the cost, which is estimated at $350.00, be taken from the capital at the credit of the Band, which now amounts to $6,520.00.

It has been shown to the satisfaction of the undersigned that a school-house is necessary and that the building when completed will properly represent capital. He would therefore respectfully recommend that authority be given by Your Excellency in Council to expend a sum not exceeding $350.00, in the erection of a school-house on the Spanish River Reserve, from the capital at the credit of the Band, in accordance with the provisions of Sec. 70 of the Indian Act as enacted by Sec. 2 of the Act 36-39 Vic., Cap. 36.

Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.
Spanish River Reserve,
12th September, 1896.

To B. W. Ross, Esq.,
Superintendent, Manitowaning,

Dear Mr. Ross:

The Indians have got through their summer work, and are only now ready to commence building the school-house. They had a Council on the 20th August, when a resolution, and the cost of the building was made and sent to you in duplicate, but as it is getting so late in the season they had another Council on 8th September about commencing on Monday 12th. It is to be built in the same place as it is more convenient to the majority of children who attend school. Oshkenahwa, an Indian has undertaken the job but they want provisions, so I went security to A. Cadotte for $7.60 which is to be paid out of the grant allowed by the Department for the building of the school-house, but I do not wish to have any further responsibility. I think the Indians require someone to superintend the work. I had as little expense put on the house, as possible, in hopes that the school-house would be ready by the end of September when the agreement ends, after which the Indian who owns this house, wants $1.50 per month for rent. This house would require a great deal of repairs to make it habitable for the winter. Please send me your word of assurance, then the Department will grant the money for the school-house and appoint Mr. Sins superintendent, who transacts most of the business for the Indians.

Awaiting your early reply

Your truly,

Carrie Morley.
13th P. S.

Have just heard that Oshkonahwa has given up the job.

C. M.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter enclosing copy of a letter from the Bishop of Algoma with suggestion for the closing of the school at Spanish River Reserve, and the sale of the building to him for mission purposes, and requiring my report on the proposal. The fact cannot be ignored that the attendance at the school has sadly dwindled, and it must appear that the closing of the school in the near future has become a necessity, although any report shows only a list of ten pupils at school and a late average of but two. I have just recently and since my inspection received a letter from Miss Morley the teacher stating that there are now six pupils regularly attending, and she has the faithful promise of these six and their parents that they will continue to attend regularly.

In view of this, as well as in view of the long and faithful service of Miss Morley, I would respectfully suggest that should the Department decide on closing the school, such closing might take effect only from the end of the current year, and that Miss Morley should be notified of the decision of the Department as soon as such decision has been arrived at.

Should the school be closed this year, the building could not be used for a long time for school purposes, and being unoccupied would rapidly deteriorate in value and fall into decay.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of February 15th 1910 No. 157217.

I beg leave to say that the desks you spoke of were placed in Spanish River School last fall. They were sent to the orders of the chief James Washikling. I cannot understand how those ten desks were sent to my orders at Thesola as I never ordered school desks without permission and when I was notified about them being ten school desks at the Station I came to the conclusion at once that they had been ordered by the Department as in your letter of July 30th last you mentioned that the Inspector stated that the desks needed repairing. I may say that the desks in the Spanish River Indian school were not worth repairing as they had been in use for about 20 years.

I beg to say that the desks were very much wanted as the old ones were so broken that a person could not lay a slate on them. I hope I have not done a grave wrong. I was well pleased to get them and had them put in the school as quickly as possible.

Dear Sir,

I was appointed last spring by the Most Rev. G. Horne, Archbishop of Kingston, to the charge of Massy mission, where part of my work consists in ministering to the Indians on Spanish River Reserve, about ten families belonging to the Anglican Communion. During the summer I have been holding services in the old school house, but find it will be impossible to carry on during the winter on account of the dilapidated condition of the building.

There are sixteen children of school age in this section of the reservation, and no provision for their education. If a teacher were found for the position, work could not be carried on in the present building.

At a meeting of the Indians held after service yesterday afternoon, I was asked by the Band through their Chief to request consideration by the Department of a new
buildings, said building to be erected and equipped at the earliest opportunity, and situated more central for the children.

May I say that the request of the Indians has my entire sympathy and support, and I believe the Archbishops as well. I hope you will take up this matter with the Department without delay, and press upon them the urgency of the situation. I shall be only too glad personally to assist in any way possible in the advancement of this work.

Hoping you in anticipation,

Yours respectfully,

Sidney F. Yeomans
Priest in Charge.
Sir,

The school house at Spanish River belongs to Spanish Band No. 2 and is in need of repairs. There has been no school since Rev. Mr. Fairburn taught there, but it has been used for church services off and on.

The building is of logs, very old, built in a place where there are no Indians now. I would suggest that if the Dept. would build a new school or have it placed in a more central location we might start a school next year.

I asked the chief councillor to make out a list of repairs to the building last summer, but did receive it until the other day.

The building is 26 x 19, long 12' high.

There will need work under the building & the roof strengthened, also the inside plastered.

The floors need repair & the window frames mended.

The chimney is not very good & also the shingles in showing signs of decay.

An excellent letter deserves from Mr. Yeomans re this building.

Yours obedient servant,

Ottawa, Nov. 19, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, enclosing a communication from the Rev. Sidney F. Yeomans, in which he requests that the school building on the Spanish River No. 2 Indian Reserve be repaired and placed in good condition, for the purpose of holding church services and as a classroom for the Indian children.

In reply I beg to say, in view of your report as to the present state of this building and the repairs that would be required, it is considered that the Department would not be warranted in undertaking any expense in this connection.

It is noted, from the Rev. Mr. Yeoman's letter, that there are 16 children of school age. Your report that the building is not centrally located has also been noted. I should be pleased to have your opinion as to whether you would recommend that a new school building be erected on a more central site. I may say that, in view of the past experience as to the poor attendance and lack of interest on the part of the Indians when the school was formerly in operation, the Department would hesitate to incur the expenditure necessary for the erection of a new building, unless conditions have materially improved and the Indians show a greater desire for the education of their children. The funds at the credit of the Band would hardly stand the expense and it would be necessary to provide the amount required from Parliamentary appropriation. If you recommend that a new school building be erected, kindly state the number of children which it should accommodate, advise us if a teacher's living quarters should be arranged for and estimate the cost of putting up the building. As there are no classes being conducted at present, the Department cannot approve of any expenditure on the old building.

Please reply at an early date, giving your views regarding the erection of a new building and as full particulars as you can concerning size required, cost, etc.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

C. F. Rothera, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.

Dear Sir:— As Rural Dean of Algoma I have recently been visiting the Spanish River Reserve at the request of the Executive Committee of our Diocese. After reporting to the Committee I have been authorized to write to your Department in their name.

We have been anxious for some time to have facilities provided for the instruction of the Indian children at our end of the Reserve. The Indian Agent, Mr. Rothera of Massalon, has been appealed to often to have written your Department with regard to this matter. As you are aware the School house is not at all conveniently situated, & is in a very bad state of repair, & for a long time now no teaching has been given to the children of our families.
I visited the Reserve on a week-day with our missionary from Moses, Rev. J.F. Yeomans, who holds service in the Schoolhouse at stated & regular intervals. There were 25 present, & the service was held. The hymns were sung in the Ojibway. It was a hearty service.

They tell me there are 17 children of school age growing up without any instruction at all.

The ideal would be a new Schoolhouse farther on where the families concerned live, & a teacher provided to give regular instruction in at least the rudiments to these children.

At least the old Schoolhouse should be put into a thorough state of repair & teaching provided.

We have under consideration the building of a little Church if the Band is willing that a small piece of land should be ceded. But this is another matter.

Our Executive Committee earnestly hope that your Department can take some action.

We meet again for our bi-annual business on Oct. 5th so that we may hear from you favorably before then.

We feel sure of your sympathy with us in our work of endeavor to help these Indians for whom we are responsible, especially their spiritual welfare.

faithfully yours,

P.S. I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Rother.

C. Wilfred Balfour.

Ottawa, December 13, 1927.

Sir:

As the new school building at Spanish River is nearly completed, it will be necessary to supply certain furnishings, such as a stove, desks, blackboard, etc. I have, therefore, to request that you will inform the Department as soon as possible what supplies are required. If any desks are required, the size and number of each size should be stated. For your information I may say that desks are manufactured in the following sizes:

| Size No. | Pupils 15-18 Yrs. | 11-14 Yrs. | 10-13 Yrs. | 7-9 Yrs. | 5-7 Yrs. |
|----------|------------------|------------|------------|----------|----------|
| 2        |                  |            |            |          |          |
| 3        |                  |            |            |          |          |
| 4        |                  |            |            |          |          |
| 5        |                  |            |            |          |          |
| 6        |                  |            |            |          |          |

It would be advisable to have each row of desks of the same size, with a front and rear seat. Please also state whether a teacher's desk and chair are necessary. It may be that there are certain supplies in the former old school building which could be used and would be satisfactory in the new building.

You might state what arrangements are made for heating the new building, and whether a stove is required.

Please also state if any blackboard is required, and, if so, you should give the length and width of same. I may say for your information that blackboard material is manufactured in 3½ and 4 foot widths and in lengths of 3 to 5 feet.

Your early reply giving the information asked for as to the furnishings required is desired in order that same can be obtained and on hand in time to open the school early in the new year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

C. F. Rothera, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Thessalon, Ont.

Ottawa, December 7, 1931.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, requesting that the Department furnish the supplies required to serve a midday lunch during the winter to the pupils of the Spanish River Indian Day School, to consist of bread, butter, cocoa and milk.

In this connection I have to say that the Department provides, in the case of certain schools, supplies for the serving of a hot drink, consisting of either tea or cocoa, with condensed milk and sugar. This drink is to supplement the lunch brought by the pupils from their homes. If you prepare a list of the supplies you require, also state what utensils you would need in the preparing and serving of the lunch, and forward same through the office of Mr. C. F. Rothera, the local Indian Agent, consideration would be given to authorizing him to purchase the supplies required.

In future, I shall be pleased if you will forward all communications regarding your school through the office of your local Indian Agent.

Your obedient servant,

Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.,
June 13th, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Miss B. Willis, teacher of the Protestant Indian Day School on the Spanish River Reserve, has made a request for a fence to be built around the school as none exists at present.

There is a fence around the R.C. school. I think that Miss Willis' request should be granted as there is a large number of cattle and horses running loose on the Spanish River Reserve in the summer time and they all seem to head for the ground around the school. This makes it unsafe for the children when they are at play and tends to distract their attention when they are in school.

The length of fence required would be approximately forty-eight rods. The cost per rod would be—wire 60¢, posts and staples 40¢, labour 60¢. The approximate costs for material and labour would be about $1.80 per rod, making a total cost of $75.80.

I would recommend that this fence be erected as soon as possible.

Yours very truly,

H. P. G. Laurence,
Indian Agent.

Ontario.

Dear Sir,

As you are aware there are many little jobs that may be done around this school both for the good of the fabric of the building, and for the edification of the children. Additional cupboards are required in the school room. Some of the desks are in need of repair. There is need of a wood box. Racks are needed in the school room. These are but a few of the little things which need to be done around here.

All of them could be done with but little expenditure of my leisure time, but all of them require tools and materials. I would be only too glad to give my time to these things, as I did in painting the interior of the school, if I were but supplied with the tools and materials.

I therefore submit for your consideration a requisition for the following:

| Item                                      | Cost |
|-------------------------------------------|------|
| General Purpose Saw                       | $1.00|
| Small Block Plane                          | $2.75|
| Claw Hammer                                | $1.00|
| STRONG Screw Driver                        | $.50 |
| Spade                                     | $1.00|
| Rake                                      | $.85 |
| Hoe                                       | $.85 |
| Gallon Linseed Oil For School Floor        | $1.60|
| 10 Yards Fine Wire Screening              | $4.00|
| Screen Moulding 100 ft                    | $3.00|
| Finished Lumber... 250 Board Ft.          | ?    |
| Sack Cement To Seal Well                  | $1.50|
| Glass Cutter                              | $.50 |
| LB. Glazers Putty                         | $.25 |

The Cement mentioned above is urgently needed. At present the well, which is in the basement, is open, and consequently, the well floods in rainy weather and in the spring, which is inconvenient; and from time to time mice fall in and are drowned, which is very unhealthy; for the drinkers of the water.

Screens are badly needed, but I think they can be made cheaper than they can be bought. There are no screens at all for the school or residence windows, and the one screen door needs re-screening. I
have therefore asked for the materials wherewith I might make the school fly-proof.

The finish has completely worn off the school-room floor. If it were painted with HOT linseed oil it would be greatly improved and would also be preserved. So I have asked for one gallon of linseed oil.

Many of the window panes are loose and some are cracked. There are some pieces of glass lying around so if I had a glass cutter and some putty I could fix up the windows as needed.

With tools and some finished lumber badly needed cupboards could easily be built in the school-room. They would repay any expense of time and money in preserving the school supplies. At present there is but one small cupboard in the school-room, and as a result of the lack of space school books and other supplies have to be piled wherever room can be found. Many other things, too, could be built.

I am fully aware that rigid economy is needed in these times, but I consider that the above things will be of great benefit, and will counteract future and larger expenditures.

Trusting that my request will meet with your approval may I remain

Sincerely yours,

Charles G. Kehler,
Teacher.

P.S. I also need:

1 Floor Broom -- Horse Hair Bristles... Cost $1.75 Approx.
1 " " " -- Corn Bristles........... " .50 "

Could these be added to the above articles, or do I have to supply them at my own expense?.

Dear Mr. Lawrence:

The pump in the school here is old and the cylinder is so worn that it is impossible to repair it further. The base of the pump, where the cylinder is joined to the intake pipe is cracked, and, though I have had it welded, an air-tight joint is no longer possible. Consequently the pump sucks air and will not raise the water from the well.

Because of the failure of the pump, I am obliged to obtain all water used in the school from the Spanish River. During the cold weather the water is not too bad, but when the weather turns warm, the river water is not safe for drinking, as into it is poured all the sewage from the town of Espanola upstream. Even now, I take the precaution of boiling the water and giving the children hot drinks rather than let them drink too much cold water.

I am, therefore, enclosing a requisition for a new pump of the same type as is now here. The approximate cost will be around $6.00 and can be purchased locally at Bower's Hardware in Massey.

Thanking you may I remain

Sincerely yours,

Charles G. Kehler

May 27, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Mr. Chas. G. Kehler of the Spanish River Reserve Anglican Day School has requested that he be supplied with material to build a much needed kitchen, to be added as a lean-to behind the school building, and for sufficient paint to paint the exterior of the entire building - all work, the building and painting to be done by him without charge.

At the back of the school room in this school there is a passageway about seven feet wide with a stair-case at one end which has in the past served as a kitchen. In the winter time this works satisfactorily but in warm weather it makes both the small room and the school room too warm when a fire is kept on in the stove continually.

As Mr. Kehler is the first married teacher who has occupied these quarters, the kitchen stove is naturally more in use now than it was in the past and some kind of a summer kitchen is badly needed.

Mr. Kehler is very interested in his work and intends staying at the school all summer. He is putting in a large garden, cleaning the school up, and is anxious to improve the place and doing whatever he can towards encouraging the Indians immediately around him in gardening. He is well thought of by the Indians and intends staying at this school as long as his services are satisfactory.

In view of the above, I would recommend that if at all possible he be granted the material
required to do this work.

I am enclosing herewith, in duplicate, a Requisition for the material required, the approximate cost of which would be $150.00.

Yours very truly,

R.F.G. Laurence
Indian Agent.

These vents are necessary to enable us to comfortably heat the upper rooms of the living quarters at this school.

At present the stove pipe from the stove in the school room passes through the bedroom, making the bedroom uncomfortably hot whenever the school room is heated.

It is proposed to pass the stove pipe through the wall dividing the school room from the dining room horizontally. These walls are metal faced and a wall flue is on hand.

This will reduce the number of elbows in the stove pipe from the present three to one—thus cutting down the fire hazard.

The Living Room and bedroom will be heated by hot air passing through the floor registers. This will make for more even temperatures all round and less stiffness. The stove pipe will be much shorter.

Dear Mr. Laurence:

In order to provide this school with a safe source of water and a sanitary method of disposal for waste will the Indian Affairs Branch consider putting in a pump and a sink with a cess pool at the following cost?

50 feet inside diameter 1½ inch pipe........$16.00
10 only couplings @ .35¢ ea..................3.50
1 " check valve.............................3.25
1 " Sand point..............................6.00
1 " Flat rimmed Sink.......................10.00
Sink fittings..............................3.00
LABOUR to drive well, construct cess pool and install sink...................30.00

Total Materials & Labour $81.75

At the present time all water, including drinking water is obtained from the Spanish River. Often this water is too muddy for safe drinking. During the times of freeze-up and break-up, getting water is dangerous, difficult and at times impossible.

At present all waste-water is merely emptied onto the ground, which is neither sanitary nor convenient. There is a definite need of both the driven well and the sink and cess-pool.

Yours truly,

Charles G. Kehler
Teacher
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

When Mr. Indian Agent Laurence was passing through here on his vacation he asked me to write to you concerning the water supply at this school.

We have, so far, spent approximately $50.00. In various places at the back of the school buildings we drove a well about 40 feet into the ground but we were unable to pierce the thick stratum of clay and tap the water beneath it. However, in another location in front of the school we found excellent water that has been classified "Class A" by the Ontario Public Health Laboratories. This water is in coarse sand about ten feet below the surface.

It is proposed to dig and crib a small well and pipe the water into the school. This work will entail the expenditure of a further $60.00, but will assure a plentiful supply of water with convenience.

Mr. Laurence asked me to write to you to ask if the Indian Affairs Branch would consider approving this expenditure. The Indian Agent will be on vacation and away from his office for another two weeks, but will be on this reserve again next week. If you so prefer a reply sent here will be handed to him on his return.

Yours truly,

October 23, 1945.

Mr. R. P. G. Laurence,
Office of the Indian Agent,
SAULT STE. MARIE, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Laurence:

As the twelve children who attend this school, all stay for lunch, I have, since my appointment almost five years ago, provided, at my own expense, hot cocoa or soup in order to supplement the lunches that the children bring.

Would you kindly approach the Indian Affairs' Branch and ask them if they would consider granting me two dollars ($2.00) per month for the months of November to March inclusive to provide these supplements.

As all the milking goats have been given to those Indian families who applied for them, we have no goats' milk for use in the school. This is what is desired for it does more to encourage the keeping of goats by Indians themselves. It also shares the work of milking rather than leaving the work of milking the entire herd on the shoulders of the teacher. At the present time, I have more applications for fresh goats that I can satisfy for some time to come.

It is therefore necessary to buy evaporated milk, soup and cocoa to serve to the children in school.

Yours truly,

Charles G. Kehler

Mr. R. F. G. Laurence,

SAULT STE. MARIE,
Ontario.

Dear Sir:

As you are aware the only means of illumination at present available at the Spanish River Reserve Anglican School is in the form of coal oil lamps. These provide but poor light and are a constant source of danger of fire. It costs about $15.00 per year for coal oil, an expenditure that, though small does not provide very good nor adequate illumination.

I have learned that it is possible to purchase a Windcharger in Massey for the total cost, including installation of $150.00. Of this sum the Bishop of the Diocese, The Rt. Rev. Wm. L. Wright, D.D., has offered $75.00. This sum has been offered and is available on call from me to the Synod Office, Sault Ste. Marie, because the Bishop desires to make life here more convenient and comfortable, and because the installation of wind-developed electric light will enable us here to give more handicraft and trade training to the young adults, as well as be less dangerous.

The Windcharger that is available at the low figure of $150.00 installed is the property of a man who lived for a short time in the country and then moved into town where hydro-electric power is available. The outfit is entirely complete, and is in good order. I asked the manager of the Deagle Light and Power Co., Massey to inspect it and he has stated that it is in good shape and that it would provide us with adequate power for the single cost of the purchase. I shall enclose a complete list of all the parts and accessories that are covered by the purchase price of $150.00.

The above mentioned manager of the Deagle Light and Power Co. (a personal friend) has promised to install the Windcharger and wire the School at no additional cost to the Department if the Indian Affairs Branch will see fit to make it available at this school by voting the other half of the purchase price, i.e. $75.00.

The outlay of $75.00 would be saved in five years at the rate of $15.00 per year; the present yearly outlay for coal oil. I am assured by many users of Windchargers that the initial cost is the sole cost for many, many years. Here we enjoy almost constant breezes from the river, and it takes but a 6@ m.p.h. breeze to generate power with the 7½ foot propeller.

If bought through the usual channels the outfit would cost about $300.00.

Would you therefore, approach the Indian Affairs Branch regarding the installation of the Windcharger at this school, and at the same time tell them of the Bishop's offer to assist in the purchase of it. Installation would include the erection of a suitable support away from the fabric of the school building.

By having wind-developed electric light at the school we will be enabled to give evening instruction to the young adults. At the present time the young adults want to come to the school to receive some handicraft and trade training but we are handicapped by lack of good and sufficient light. We have tools and materials to use in this training, and through the kindness of friends we expect to get more.

Yours truly,

Charles G. Kehler,
The Rev. Charles G. Kehler,
Teacher.

P.S. Mr. Geo. King, manager of the Deagle Light and Power Co., Massey, has promised to donate additional fixtures if necessary if the Indian Affairs Branch approves the installation of the Windcharger.

3 only shades for ceiling lights in School Room

MASSEY Ontario,
16th April, 1947

The attached Requisitions for School Material are sent in at this time so as to enable the Stationery Branch and your office to send out the authorized materials for the next academic year before the end of the current year. We now have sufficient good cupboard space in which to store the supplies. It may be that by being early some congestion may be avoided.

You will note that among other things a projector is requisitioned. Either a Slide Projector or a Film Projector or both would be a great educational help, for the young AND the Adults. I have long known that both Slides and films can be obtained from various Governmental Departments, both Federal and Provincial. Industrial Advertising Agencies, Travel Agencies and others make films and slides available. We have six volt current available here and I have had experience when in the Lesser Slave Lake country with the type of projector I now have in mind. When in the North I used the battery of my car to provide the current, keeping the car motor running to generate enough current. With the Wincharger here and the school Room wired the current is always handy. I could obtain educational films at no cost to the Department which would further the education of the people here if a projector, preferably a 16 mm. Film projector adapted for six volt direct current were provided. Please consider this request as favourably as possible.

Copied:
CS

Charles G. Kehler,

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES.

Enclosed please find requisition for school material and letter from Mr. C.G. Kehler, teacher of the Spanish River C.E. Indian Day School, Spanish River Reserve, requesting among other things a slide projector or a film projector.

If a film projector were supplied, it could be used as well for showing educational films at the Community Hall, by use of car batteries for power.

Mr. Kehler's school is small and only serves a small portion of the reserve, while the Community Hall is about two miles from the Anglican School and is situated at the centre of the population, near the R.C. school.

With reference to the Homemaker's Club mentioned in his letter, I intend to get this club organized on my next visit to this reserve.

As Mr. Kehler has now disposed of the goats to the Indians on the reserve, it was agreed that the goat barn could serve a good purpose by being turned into a workshop for the young men of the reserve, who are interested in this work.

R.P.G. Laurence
Indian Agent

Memorandum:

Classroom Inspection Report -
Spanish River C.E. Indian Day School.

Teacher - W.H. Thompson - No Certificate -
No Experience - One Year Tutor Teacher - Age 28.

This teacher was formerly attached to the Society of St. John Evangeline at Bracebridge. He is more interested in missionary activities than in teaching at this school. When I arrived at the school at nine fifteen he had not yet had his breakfast and it seemed evident that school would only begin at nine thirty or a quarter of ten. Some children had drifted in about nine fifteen and they were still arriving at ten thirty. Mr. Thompson seems afraid that the Indian parents might resent his insistence that the children arrive at nine o'clock. Evidently this would interfere with his missionary activities. He informed me that he was keeping these children in after school in order to make up lost time. I left no doubt in his mind as to the Department's attitude with regard to the opening of school on time. Enrolments:

| Grade | Present |
|-------|---------|
| 1     | 6       |
| 2     | 3       |
| 4     | 3       |
| 5     | 3       |
| 6     | 1       |

The classroom is small but well lighted with four windows on one side and one on the other. There is a side room which was used as a work shop by a former teacher and is now used for Homemaker's Club meetings. The classroom is lined with beaver board walls and is on the whole quite satisfactory for this small school.
There is a living-room and kitchen at the back of the school and three bedrooms above the classroom. Vents in the ceiling of the classroom heat the rooms above. Electricity is provided by a wind driven charger. There is a pump in the corner of the classroom. In Spelling three failed and one passed. In Arithmetic four failed and one passed. This teacher is willing enough but is accomplishing little. The instructions lose purpose and motive. These children need a strong teacher. They neither speak out nor read well. Neither does the teacher. With a good teacher this could be a bright and interesting school.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

PP/HH.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to acknowledge your letter dated November 10th, 1948, regarding requisition for a hammer, saw, screwdriver, brace and bit for the Spanish River C.E. School.

I will see that if the equipment is supplied this time, that it will remain in the school.

Extract from Inspection Report on the Spanish River C.E. Indian Day School dated November 19th made by Regional Supervisor Matters. Original on file # 77-13.

The Protestant day school on this reserve has very poor accommodation for the teacher, and the heating system, (by means of stoves) somewhat precarious, there have also been a number of complaints about the building being cold.

There is no basement in the school, and I think it would advisable to build a basement and install a furnace to provide a good heating system, both safe and efficient, the teachers quarters were good enough for a single man, but not adequate for a married teacher with a family. I favour the employment of married teachers, as usually they are more stable and settled and with the provision of suitable living quarters we are more liable to retain or be able to engage more married teachers, so would recommend that the necessary alterations be made to the building.
November 3, 1948.
